questions.question: What is thrashing in OS?
questions.explanation: Thrashing occurs when system spends more time paging than executing.

questions.question: What is a process?
questions.explanation: A process is a program in execution with its own memory space.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of children a binary tree node can have?
questions.explanation: By definition, a binary tree node can have at most 2 children.

questions.question: In a stack, which operation is used to add an element?
questions.explanation: Push operation adds an element to the top of the stack.

questions.question: Which algorithm is used to find shortest path in unweighted graph?
questions.explanation: BFS finds shortest path in unweighted graphs by exploring level by level.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in an array by index?
questions.explanation: Array elements can be accessed directly using index in constant time O(1).

questions.question: What does SQL stand for?
questions.explanation: SQL stands for Structured Query Language used for database operations.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of linear search in an unsorted array?
questions.explanation: Linear search checks each element sequentially, taking O(n) time in worst case.

questions.question: Which SQL command is used to retrieve data?
questions.explanation: SELECT command is used to retrieve data from database tables.

questions.question: What is ACID in database transactions?
questions.explanation: ACID stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability - transaction properties.

questions.question: Which data structure uses FIFO (First In First Out) principle?
questions.explanation: Queue follows FIFO principle where first element inserted is first to be removed.

questions.question: Binary search requires the array to be:
questions.explanation: Binary search only works on sorted arrays as it relies on comparison.

questions.question: What is the height of a tree with only one node (root)?
questions.explanation: Height of a tree with single node is 0 (distance from root to itself).

questions.question: Which layer of OSI model handles routing?
questions.explanation: Network layer (Layer 3) is responsible for routing packets.

questions.question: What is the default subnet mask for Class C network?
questions.explanation: Class C networks use 255.255.255.0 as default subnet mask.

questions.question: What is normalization in databases?
questions.explanation: Normalization is the process of organizing data to reduce redundancy.

questions.question: Which sorting algorithm has the best average-case time complexity?
questions.explanation: Merge Sort has O(n log n) average-case complexity, better than O(n²) algorithms.

questions.question: Which scheduling algorithm can cause starvation?
questions.explanation: Priority scheduling can starve low-priority processes indefinitely.

questions.question: What is the main function of an operating system?
questions.explanation: OS manages hardware and software resources of a computer system.

questions.question: What does IP stand for?
questions.explanation: IP stands for Internet Protocol, used for addressing and routing.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of queues needed to implement a priority queue?
questions.explanation: A single queue with proper ordering can implement priority queue.

questions.question: Which isolation level prevents dirty reads?
questions.explanation: Read Committed and higher levels prevent dirty reads.

questions.question: Network has bandwidth 1 Gbps and propagation delay 10 ms. What is bandwidth-delay product?
questions.explanation: BDP = 10⁹ bits/sec × 10×10⁻³ sec = 10⁷ bits = 1.25 MB.

questions.question: What is the purpose of TLB in paging?
questions.explanation: TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer) caches page table entries for fast access.

questions.question: In a max heap with n elements, what is the time complexity to find minimum element?
questions.explanation: Minimum element in max heap is at leaf node, requiring O(n) time to find.

questions.question: Consider a binary search tree with n nodes. What is the worst-case time complexity for searching an element?
questions.explanation: In worst case (skewed tree), BST degenerates to linked list, requiring O(n) time.

questions.question: TCP sender window 8 KB, RTT 100 ms. Maximum throughput?
questions.explanation: Throughput = 8 KB / 0.1 s = 80 KB/s = 640 Kbps.

questions.question: What is the time complexity of T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n?
questions.explanation: Using Master's theorem case 2, T(n) = O(n log n).

questions.question: Kruskal's algorithm uses which data structure for cycle detection?
questions.explanation: Kruskal's uses Union-Find (Disjoint Set) for efficient cycle detection.

questions.question: What is efficiency of pure ALOHA?
questions.explanation: Pure ALOHA has maximum efficiency of 1/(2e) ≈ 18.4%.

questions.question: In producer-consumer problem, what prevents race condition?
questions.explanation: Mutex, Semaphore, and Monitor all can prevent race conditions.

questions.question: In Go-Back-N with window 7, if frame 3 lost, how many retransmitted?
questions.explanation: Frames 3,4,5,6 need retransmission (4 frames) in Go-Back-N.

questions.question: In dynamic programming, what is time complexity of 0/1 Knapsack with n items and capacity W?
questions.explanation: DP table has dimensions n×W, each cell takes O(1) time.

questions.question: Minimum tables needed for many-to-many relationship?
questions.explanation: Need 3 tables: two entity tables and one junction table.

questions.question: Bits required for subnet mask to divide Class B into 64 subnets?
questions.explanation: 2⁶ = 64 subnets, so 6 bits needed for subnet ID.

questions.question: What is the purpose of indexing in databases?
questions.explanation: Indexing creates data structures for faster data retrieval.

questions.question: Which problem is NP-Complete?
questions.explanation: Vertex Cover is NP-Complete. Others are in P.

questions.question: Which page replacement algorithm suffers from Belady's anomaly?
questions.explanation: FIFO can have more page faults with more frames (Belady's anomaly).

questions.question: What is the space complexity of BFS traversal on a graph with V vertices and E edges?
questions.explanation: BFS uses queue which can hold at most V vertices at a time.

questions.question: Consider R(A,B,C,D) with FD: A→B, B→C, C→D. What is highest normal form?
questions.explanation: A is key. B,C are partial dependencies, violating 3NF but satisfying 2NF.

questions.question: Page replacement: Working set model with window size Δ. What does it represent?
questions.explanation: Working set is set of pages referenced in last Δ time units.

questions.question: System with 4 processes P1-P4, 3 resource types A,B,C with instances (10,5,7). Current allocation: P1(0,1,0), P2(2,0,0), P3(3,0,2), P4(2,1,1). Max need: P1(7,5,3), P2(3,2,2), P3(9,0,2), P4(2,2,2). Is system in safe state?
questions.explanation: Available=(3,3,4). Safe sequence exists: P2→P4→P1→P3, so safe state.

questions.question: B+ tree order 5, height 3 (including root). Maximum number of keys?
questions.explanation: Max keys = 4×5²×5 = 4×125 = 500 (approximately 3124 with proper calculation).

questions.question: Fibonacci heap: What is amortized time for decrease-key operation?
questions.explanation: Fibonacci heap provides O(1) amortized time for decrease-key.

questions.question: Query optimization: Join of R(1000 tuples) and S(2000 tuples). Block nested loop join with 5 buffer pages. How many block accesses?
questions.explanation: Depends on block size and buffer management, approximately 400000 accesses.

questions.question: System with 5 processes, each needs max 3 resources, 10 total resources. Minimum to avoid deadlock?
questions.explanation: Using (n-1)×(m-1)+1: (5-1)×(3-1)+1=9. Need 13 to guarantee no deadlock.

questions.question: Two-level page table: Outer table 1024 entries, each inner table 1024 entries, page size 4KB. Logical address space?
What is time complexity of T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n log n?
questions.explanation: Using Master's theorem case 2 with extra log factor, T(n) = O(n log² n).

questions.question: AVL tree with n nodes. What is maximum number of rotations needed for single insertion?
questions.explanation: At most 2 rotations (double rotation) needed to rebalance after insertion.

questions.question: A queue is implemented using two stacks S1 and S2. Element enqueued by pushing to S1. To dequeue, if S2 empty, all from S1 popped and pushed to S2, then top of S2 popped. What is amortized time complexity of dequeue?
questions.explanation: Using amortized analysis, each element moved at most twice, giving O(1) amortized time.

questions.question: Selective Repeat ARQ: Window size 7, sequence number space 8. Can it work correctly?
questions.explanation: For SR, sequence space must be ≥ 2×window size. 8 < 2×7, so won't work correctly.

questions.question: String matching: KMP algorithm preprocessing time for pattern of length m?
questions.explanation: KMP builds failure function in O(m) time.

questions.question: IPv4 fragmentation: Packet 4000 bytes, MTU 1500 bytes, header 20 bytes. How many fragments?
questions.explanation: Data per fragment = 1480 (multiple of 8). Need 3 fragments for 3980 bytes data.

questions.question: Network: 1 Gbps bandwidth, 20 ms RTT, packet size 1 KB. Maximum throughput with stop-and-wait?
questions.explanation: Throughput = packet size / RTT = 1KB / 0.02s = 50 KB/s = 400 Kbps.

questions.question: Approximation ratio of greedy algorithm for vertex cover problem?
questions.explanation: Greedy vertex cover has 2-approximation ratio.
